Description: Tinned copper alloy hand mirror with an elaborate silver handle which is convex above and flat underneath, spreading out in the form of a volute where it joins the mirror; at the other end it terminates in a uraeus; relatively fragile, some cracks.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Found by locals looting the site between 1884-5 “south-west of the town at a high part, lying in the loose dust among the houses”
Curator's comments: This mirror is a simpler version of elaborate silver mirrors known from Pompeii (Guzzo 2006, 223, no. 390; 101, no 94), although the uraeus cobra handle is unique. The striking cobra (which was once crowned with a headdress, probably a sun disc framed by horns) is a representation of I’rt or Uraeus, the protective cobra goddess represented on the crown of the Pharaoh-Emperor, also associated with the cobra goddesses Wadjt of the Nile Delta and Renetutet of the Fayum and subsequently amalgamated as Renetutet-Isis-Hathor, known in Greek as Hermouthis. Guzzo, P.G. 2006, Argenti a Pompei, Milan.
Bibliographic references: Silver / Catalogue of the Silver Plate (Greek, Etruscan And Roman) in the British Museum (107)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 44, pl. XXVIII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (RA.01)
